channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: [Virtual Event] Shields Up: Key Technologies Reshaping Cybersecurity Defenses
Munich Security Conference: Cyber Threats Lead G7 Risk Index, Disinformation Ranks Third
item.description: G7 countries ranked cyber-attacks as the top risk, while BICS members placed cyber threats only as the eighth most pressing risk

item.title: Malicious Chrome Extensions Caught Stealing Business Data, Emails, and Browsing History
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a malicious Google Chrome extension that's designed to steal data associated with Meta Business Suite and Facebook Business Manager. The extension, named CL Suite by @CLMasters (ID: jkphinfhmfkckkcnifhjiplhfoiefffl), is marketed as a way to scrape Meta Business Suite data, remove verification pop-ups, and generate two-factor authentication (2FA) codes.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fake AI Assistants in Google Chrome Web Store Steal Passwords and Spy on Emails
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of users have downloaded malicious AI extensions masquerading as ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok and others, warn cybersecurity researchers at LayerX

item.title: npm’s Update to Harden Their Supply Chain, and Points to Consider
item.description: In December 2025, in response to the Sha1-Hulud incident, npm completed a major authentication overhaul intended to reduce supply-chain attacks. While the overhaul is a solid step forward, the changes don’t make npm projects immune from supply-chain attacks. npm is still susceptible to malware attacks – here’s what you need to know for a safer Node community. Let’s start with the original
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Observe In-the-Wild Exploitation of BeyondTrust CVSS 9.9 Vulnerability
item.description: Threat actors have started to exploit a recently disclosed critical security flaw impacting BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products, according to watchTowr. "Overnight we observed first in-the-wild exploitation of BeyondTrust across our global sensors," Ryan Dewhurst, head of threat intelligence at watchTowr, said in a post on X. "Attackers are abusing
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Ivanti EPMM Zero-Day Bugs Spark Exploit Frenzy — Again
item.description: It's time to phase out the &quot;patch and pray&quot; approach, eliminate needless public interfaces, and enforce authentication controls, one expert says.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Booz Allen Announces General Availability of Vellox Reverser to Automate Malware Defense
item.description: The AI-powered product delivers expert-grade malware analysis and reverse engineering in minutes.

item.title: SpecterOps Launches BloodHound Scentry to Accelerate the Practice of Identity Attack Path Management
item.description: Drawing on years of adversary tradecraft, SpecterOps experts work alongside customers to analyze and eliminate attack paths, protect critical assets, and stay ahead of emerging threats.

item.title: Gone With the Shame: One in Two Americans Are Reluctant to Talk About Romance Scam Incidents
item.description: Men should take extra care on Valentine’s Day because they are nearly twice as likely as women to fall victim to romance scams.

item.title: Those 'Summarize With AI' Buttons May Be Lying to You
item.description: Microsoft uncovered AI recommendation poisoning in 31 companies across 14 industries, and turnkey tools make it trivially easy to pull off.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Critical Apple Flaw Exploited in ‘Sophisticated’ Attacks, Company Urges Rapid Patching
item.description: <p>Apple urges users to update after patching CVE-2026-20700, a zero-day flaw exploited in sophisticated targeted attacks across multiple devices.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-apple-zero-day-cve-update-february-2026/">Critical Apple Flaw Exploited in ‘Sophisticated’ Attacks, Company Urges Rapid Patching</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: Microsoft’s February Patch Tuesday Fixes 6 Zero-Days Under Attack
item.description: <p>Microsoft patches 58 vulnerabilities, including six actively exploited zero-days across Windows, Office, and RDP, as CISA sets a March 3 deadline.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-patch-tuesday-six-zero-days-february-2026/">Microsoft’s February Patch Tuesday Fixes 6 Zero-Days Under Attack</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: Google Reports State-Backed Hackers Using Gemini AI for Recon and Attack Support
item.description: Google on Thursday said it observed the North Korea-linked threat actor known as UNC2970 using its generative artificial intelligence (AI) model Gemini to conduct reconnaissance on its targets, as various hacking groups continue to weaponize the tool for accelerating various phases of the cyber attack life cycle, enabling information operations, and even conducting model extraction attacks. "The
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Lazarus Campaign Plants Malicious Packages in npm and PyPI Ecosystems
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: World Leaks Ransomware Group Adds Stealthy, Custom Malware ‘RustyRocket’ to Attacks
item.description: Accenture Cybersecurity warns over difficult to detect, “sophisticated toolset” being deployed as part of extortion campaigns

item.title: Nation-State Hackers Embrace Gemini AI for Malicious Campaigns, Google Finds
item.description: Google researchers found that government-backed hackers now use AI throughout the whole attack lifecycle

item.title: 3D Printer Surveillance
item.description: <p>New York is <a href="https://blog.adafruit.com/2026/02/03/new-york-wants-to-ctrlaltdelete-your-3d-printer/">contemplating</a> a bill that adds surveillance to 3D printers:</p> <blockquote><p>New York’s 2026­2027 executive budget bill (S.9005 / A.10005) includes language that should alarm every maker, educator, and small manufacturer in the state. Buried in Part C is a provision requiring all 3D printers sold or delivered in New York to include &#8220;blocking technology.&#8221; This is defined as software or firmware that <i>scans every print file</i> through a &#8220;firearms blueprint detection algorithm&#8221; and refuses to print anything it flags as a potential firearm or firearm component...</i></p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: AI Prompt RCE, Claude 0-Click, RenEngine Loader, Auto 0-Days & 25+ Stories
item.description: Threat activity this week shows one consistent signal — attackers are leaning harder on what already works. Instead of flashy new exploits, many operations are built around quiet misuse of trusted tools, familiar workflows, and overlooked exposures that sit in plain sight. Another shift is how access is gained versus how it’s used. Initial entry points are getting simpler, while post-compromise
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI Skills Represent Dangerous New Attack Surface, Says TrendAI
item.description: New TrendAI report warns that most security tools can’t protect against attacks on AI skills artifacts

item.title: The CTEM Divide: Why 84% of Security Programs Are Falling Behind
item.description: A new 2026 market intelligence study of 128 enterprise security decision-makers (available here) reveals a stark divide forming between organizations – one that has nothing to do with budget size or industry and everything to do with a single framework decision. Organizations implementing Continuous Threat Exposure Management (CTEM) demonstrate 50% better attack surface visibility, 23-point
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Naming and shaming: How ransomware groups tighten the screws on victims
item.description: When corporate data is exposed on a dedicated leak site, the consequences linger long after the attack fades from the news cycle

item.title: Time to Exploit Plummets as N-Day Flaws Dominate
item.description: Flashpoint warns of a dramatic drop in the average time between vulnerability disclosure and exploitation

item.title: Senegalese Data Breaches Expose Lack of 'Security Maturity'
item.description: Green Blood Group steals personal records and biometric data of the West African nation's nearly 20 million residents.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: 83% of Ivanti EPMM Exploits Linked to Single IP on Bulletproof Hosting Infrastructure
item.description: A significant chunk of the exploitation attempts targeting a newly disclosed security flaw in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) can be traced back to a single IP address on bulletproof hosting infrastructure offered by PROSPERO. Threat intelligence firm GreyNoise said it recorded 417 exploitation sessions from 8 unique source IP addresses between February 1 and 9, 2026. An estimated 346
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Proofpoint Acquires Acuvity to Deliver AI Security and Governance Across the Agentic Workspace
Apple Fixes Exploited Zero-Day Affecting iOS, macOS, and Other Devices
item.description: Apple on Wednesday released iOS, iPadOS, macOS Tahoe, tvOS, watchOS, and visionOS updates to address a zero-day flaw that it said has been exploited in sophisticated cyber attacks. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-20700 (CVSS score: 7.8), has been described as a memory corruption issue in dyld, Apple's Dynamic Link Editor. Successful exploitation of the vulnerability could allow an
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Patches Windows Flaw Causing VPN Disruptions
item.description: <p>Microsoft patches CVE-2026-21525, an actively exploited RasMan flaw that can crash Windows VPN services and disrupt remote access.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-rasman-cve-vpn/">Microsoft Patches Windows Flaw Causing VPN Disruptions</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: North Korea's UNC1069 Hammers Crypto Firms With AI
item.description: In moving away from traditional banks to focus on Web3 companies, the threat actor is leveraging LLMs, deepfakes, legitimate platforms, and ClickFix.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: How to Stay on Top of Future Threats With a Cutting-Edge SOC
item.description: CISOs should focus on harnessing and securing AI and building new skills among their people. Vision and change management can transform security.
item.dc:creator: Richard Thurston

item.title: Automaker Secures the Supply Chain With Developer-Friendly Platform
item.description: How a platform engineering team embeds supply chain security into infrastructure without slowing developers.
item.dc:creator: Joan Goodchild

item.title: First Malicious Outlook Add-In Found Stealing 4,000+ Microsoft Credentials
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered what they said is the first known malicious Microsoft Outlook add-in detected in the wild. In this unusual supply chain attack detailed by Koi Security, an unknown attacker claimed the domain associated with a now-abandoned legitimate add-in to serve a fake Microsoft login page, stealing over 4,000 credentials in the process. The activity has been
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: From 10M to 25M: Conduent Breach Balloons Into One of 2025’s Largest
item.description: <p>The Conduent ransomware attack has grown to impact 25 million Americans, exposing Social Security numbers and medical data in one of 2025’s largest breaches.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-conduent-ransomware-breach-25m/">From 10M to 25M: Conduent Breach Balloons Into One of 2025’s Largest</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Joseph Ofonagoro

item.title: North Korean Hackers Use Deepfake Video Calls to Target Crypto Firms
item.description: Campaign combines stolen Telegram accounts, fake Zoom calls and ClickFix attacks to deploy infostealer malware

item.title: Kimwolf Botnet Swamps Anonymity Network I2P
item.description: For the past week, the massive "Internet of Things" (IoT) botnet known as Kimwolf has been disrupting the The Invisible Internet Project (I2P), a decentralized, encrypted communications network designed to anonymize and secure online communications. I2P users started reporting disruptions in the network around the same time the Kimwolf botmasters began relying on it to evade takedown attempts against the botnet's control servers.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: APT36 and SideCopy Launch Cross-Platform RAT Campaigns Against Indian Entities
item.description: Indian defense sector and government-aligned organizations have been targeted by multiple campaigns that are designed to compromise Windows and Linux environments with remote access trojans capable of stealing sensitive data and ensuring continued access to infected machines. The campaigns are characterized by the use of malware families like Geta RAT, Ares RAT, and DeskRAT, which are often
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Rewiring Democracy Ebook is on Sale
item.description: <p>I just noticed that the ebook version of <a href="https://www.schneier.com/books/rewiring-democracy/"><cite>Rewriring Democracy</cite></a> is on sale for $5 on <a href="https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0DTNZ2H86">Amazon</a><a href="https://www.schneier.com/books/rewiring-democracy/">, </a><a href="https://books.apple.com/us/book/rewiring-democracy/id6740839808">Apple Books</a><a href="https://www.schneier.com/books/rewiring-democracy/">, </a><a href="https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/rewiring-democracy-bruce-schneier/1146990469?ean=9780262384407">Barnes &#38; Noble</a><a href="https://www.schneier.com/books/rewiring-democracy/">, </a><a href="https://www.booksamillion.com/p/Rewiring-Democracy/Bruce-Schneier/Q247907742">Books A Million</a><a href="https://www.schneier.com/books/rewiring-democracy/">, </a><a href="https://play.google.com/store/books/details?id=QcNAEQAAQBAJ">Google Play</a><a href="https://www.schneier.com/books/rewiring-democracy/">, </a><a href="https://www.kobo.com/us/en/ebook/rewiring-democracy">Kobo</a>, and presumably everywhere else in the US. I have no idea how long this will last.</p> <p>Also, Amazon has a <a href="https://www.amazon.com/Rewiring-Democracy-Transform-Government-Citizenship/dp/0262049945">coupon</a> that brings the hardcover price down to $20. You&#8217;ll see the discount at checkout.</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: AI Rising: Do We Know Enough About the Data Populating It?
item.description: Organizations remain reluctant to address the fact that AI can dangerously expose business operations as well as personal data.
item.dc:creator: Adam Strange

item.title: Top Cyber Industry Defenses Spike CO2 Emissions
item.description: Organizations can improve their climate footprints by optimizing two specific cybersecurity protections, without incurring added risks.

item.title: Over 60 Software Vendors Issue Security Fixes Across OS, Cloud, and Network Platforms
item.description: It's Patch Tuesday, which means a number of software vendors have released patches for various security vulnerabilities impacting their products and services. Microsoft issued fixes for 59 flaws, including six actively exploited zero-days in various Windows components that could be abused to bypass security features, escalate privileges, and trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. Elsewhere
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: US Court Hands Crypto Scammer 20 Years in $73m Case
item.description: A federal court has sentenced crypto-scammer Daren Li to 20 years in absentia

item.title: Prompt Injection Via Road Signs
item.description: <p>Interesting research: &#8220;<a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/2510.00181">CHAI: Command Hijacking Against Embodied AI</a>.&#8221;</p> <blockquote><p><b>Abstract:</b> Embodied Artificial Intelligence (AI) promises to handle edge cases in robotic vehicle systems where data is scarce by using common-sense reasoning grounded in perception and action to generalize beyond training distributions and adapt to novel real-world situations. These capabilities, however, also create new security risks. In this paper, we introduce CHAI (Command Hijacking against embodied AI), a new class of prompt-based attacks that exploit the multimodal language interpretation abilities of Large Visual-Language Models (LVLMs). CHAI embeds deceptive natural language instructions, such as misleading signs, in visual input, systematically searches the token space, builds a dictionary of prompts, and guides an attacker model to generate Visual Attack Prompts. We evaluate CHAI on four LVLM agents; drone emergency landing, autonomous driving, and aerial object tracking, and on a real robotic vehicle. Our experiments show that CHAI consistently outperforms state-of-the-art attacks. By exploiting the semantic and multimodal reasoning strengths of next-generation embodied AI systems, CHAI underscores the urgent need for defenses that extend beyond traditional adversarial robustness...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: FIRST Forecasts Record-Breaking 50,000+ CVEs in 2026
item.description: This year should break all the records in terms of vulnerability disclosed, reaching or even surpassing 50,000 new CVEs disclosed

item.title: Exposed Training Open the Door for Crypto-Mining in Fortune 500 Cloud Environments
item.description: Intentionally vulnerable training applications are widely used for security education, internal testing, and product demonstrations. Tools such as OWASP Juice Shop, DVWA, Hackazon, and bWAPP are designed to be insecure by default, making them useful for learning how common attack techniques work in controlled environments. The issue is not the applications themselves, but how they are often
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Patches 59 Vulnerabilities Including Six Actively Exploited Zero-Days
item.description: Microsoft on Tuesday released security updates to address a set of 59 flaws across its software, including six vulnerabilities that it said have been exploited in the wild. Of the 59 flaws, five are rated Critical, 52 are rated Important, and two are rated Moderate in severity. Twenty-five of the patched vulnerabilities have been classified as privilege escalation, followed by remote code
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: SSHStalker Botnet Uses IRC C2 to Control Linux Systems via Legacy Kernel Exploits
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new botnet operation called SSHStalker that relies on the Internet Relay Chat (IRC) communication protocol for command-and-control (C2) purposes. "The toolset blends stealth helpers with legacy-era Linux exploitation: Alongside log cleaners (utmp/wtmp/lastlog tampering) and rootkit-class artifacts, the actor keeps a large back-catalog of
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Fixes Six Zero Day Vulnerability in February Patch Tuesday
item.description: Six actively exploited zero-day bug have been patched by Microsoft

item.title: North Korea-Linked UNC1069 Uses AI Lures to Attack Cryptocurrency Organizations
item.description: The North Korea-linked threat actor known as UNC1069 has been observed targeting the cryptocurrency sector to steal sensitive data from Windows and macOS systems with the ultimate goal of facilitating financial theft. "The intrusion relied on a social engineering scheme involving a compromised Telegram account, a fake Zoom meeting, a ClickFix infection vector, and reported usage of AI-generated
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Asia Fumbles With Throttling Back Telnet Traffic in Region
item.description: Only Taiwan made the top 10 list of governments, effectively blocking the threat-ridden protocol, but overall, the region lagged in curbing Telnet traffic.

item.description: Organizations that have exposed their instances of Web Help Desk to the public Internet have inadvertently made them prime targets for attackers.

item.description: Microsoft today released updates to fix more than 50 security holes in its Windows operating systems and other software, including patches for a whopping six "zero-day" vulnerabilities that attackers are already exploiting in the wild.

item.title: 10K Claude Desktop Users Exposed by Zero-Click Vulnerability
item.description: <p>A zero-click flaw in Anthropic’s Claude Desktop Extensions allows attackers to trigger remote code execution via Google Calendar events.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-claude-desktop-zero-click-vulnerability/">10K Claude Desktop Users Exposed by Zero-Click Vulnerability</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.description: The information technology (IT) workers associated with the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) are now applying to remote positions using real LinkedIn accounts of individuals they're impersonating, marking a new escalation of the fraudulent scheme. "These profiles often have verified workplace emails and identity badges, which DPRK operatives hope will make their fraudulent
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: Ironically, security by obscurity has helped prevent dangerous OT attacks in recent years. It won't be that way forever.

item.title: Phorpiex Phishing Delivers Low-Noise Global Group Ransomware
item.description: High-volume phishing campaign delivers Phorpiex malware via malicious Windows Shortcut files

item.title: Reynolds Ransomware Embeds BYOVD Driver to Disable EDR Security Tools
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of an emergent ransomware family dubbed Reynolds that comes embedded with a built-in bring your own vulnerable driver (BYOVD) component for defense evasion purposes within the ransomware payload itself. BYOVD refers to an adversarial technique that abuses legitimate but flawed driver software to escalate privileges and disable Endpoint Detection
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: “Digital Parasite” Warning as Attackers Favor Stealth for Extortion
item.description: Picus Security warns of the increasingly sophisticated ways malicious activity is staying hidden

item.description: ZeroDayRAT is a new mobile spyware targeting Android and iOS, offering attackers persistent access

item.title: From Ransomware to Residency: Inside the Rise of the Digital Parasite
item.description: Are ransomware and encryption still the defining signals of modern cyberattacks, or has the industry been too fixated on noise while missing a more dangerous shift happening quietly all around them? According to Picus Labs’ new Red Report 2026, which analyzed over 1.1 million malicious files and mapped 15.5 million adversarial actions observed across 2025, attackers are no longer optimizing for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fortinet Patches Critical SQLi Flaw Enabling Unauthenticated Code Execution
item.description:
Fortinet has released security updates to address a critical flaw impacting FortiClientEMS that could lead to the execution of arbitrary code on susceptible systems. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-21643, has a CVSS rating of 9.1 out of a maximum of 10.0.
"An improper neutralization of special elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') vulnerability [CWE-89] in FortiClientEMS may
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Singapore Takes Down Chinese Hackers Targeting Telco Networks
item.description: Operation Cyber Guardian was Singapore’s largest and longest running anti-cyber threat law enforcement operation

item.title: AI-Generated Text and the Detection Arms Race
item.description: <p>In 2023, the science fiction literary magazine <cite>Clarkesworld</cite> <a href="https://www.npr.org/2023/02/24/1159286436/ai-chatbot-chatgpt-magazine-&#60;cite&#62;Clarkesworld&#60;/cite&#62;-artificial-intelligence">stopped accepting</a> new submissions because so many were generated by artificial intelligence. Near as the editors could tell, many submitters pasted the magazine’s detailed story guidelines into an AI and sent in the results. And they weren’t alone. Other fiction magazines have also <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/2/25/23613752/ai-generated-short-stories-literary-magazines-&#60;cite&#62;Clarkesworld&#60;/cite&#62;-science-fiction">reported a high number</a> of AI-generated submissions.</p> <p>This is only one example of a ubiquitous trend. A legacy system relied on the difficulty of writing and cognition to limit volume. Generative AI overwhelms the system because the humans on the receiving end can’t keep up...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: NCSC Issues Warning Over “Severe” Cyber-Attacks Targeting Critical National Infrastructure
item.description: NCSC call firms to ‘act now’ following disruptive malware attacks targeting Polish energy providers

This investment came from the well-known investment firm Hillhouse Capital, bringing ZAST.AI's total funding close to $10 million. This marks a recognition from leading capital markets of a new solution: ending the era of high false positive rates in security tools and making every alert
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

The incident took place on January 29, 2026, when a mail server that was not updated to the latest version was compromised, the company's Chief Commercial Officer, Derek Curtis, said. item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: China-Linked UNC3886 Targets Singapore Telecom Sector in Cyber Espionage Campaign
item.description: The Cyber Security Agency (CSA) of Singapore on Monday revealed that the China-nexus cyber espionage group known as UNC3886 targeted its telecommunications sector. "UNC3886 had launched a deliberate, targeted, and well-planned campaign against Singapore's telecommunications sector," CSA said. "All four of Singapore's major telecommunications operators ('telcos') – M1, SIMBA Telecom, Singtel, and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Two Connecticut Men Charged In Alleged $3m Gambling Fraud Scheme
item.description: Two Connecticut men face federal charges for a $3m scheme targeting online gambling platforms

item.title: VoidLink Malware Exhibits Multi-Cloud Capabilities and AI Code
item.description: VoidLink, a Linux-based C2 framework, facilitates credential theft, data exfiltration across clouds

item.title: SolarWinds Web Help Desk Exploited for RCE in Multi-Stage Attacks on Exposed Servers
item.description: Microsoft has revealed that it observed a multi‑stage intrusion that involved the threat actors exploiting internet‑exposed SolarWinds Web Help Desk (WHD) instances to obtain initial access and move laterally across the organization's network to other high-value assets. That said, the Microsoft Defender Security Research Team said it's not clear whether the activity weaponized recently
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Flickr’s 35M Users Affected by Third-Party Data Exposure
item.description: <p>Flickr disclosed a data exposure tied to a third-party email provider, highlighting how external service vulnerabilities can put millions of users at risk.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-flickr-third-party-email-data-exposure/">Flickr’s 35M Users Affected by Third-Party Data Exposure</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: AI Skill Malware, 31Tbps DDoS, Notepad++ Hack, LLM Backdoors and More
item.description: Cyber threats are no longer coming from just malware or exploits. They’re showing up inside the tools, platforms, and ecosystems organizations use every day. As companies connect AI, cloud apps, developer tools, and communication systems, attackers are following those same paths. A clear pattern this week: attackers are abusing trust. Trusted updates, trusted marketplaces, trusted apps, even
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: LLMs are Getting a Lot Better and Faster at Finding and Exploiting Zero-Days
item.description: <p>This is <a href="https://red.anthropic.com/2026/zero-days/">amazing</a>:</p> <blockquote><p>Opus 4.6 is notably better at finding high-severity vulnerabilities than previous models and a sign of how quickly things are moving. Security teams have been automating vulnerability discovery for years, investing heavily in fuzzing infrastructure and custom harnesses to find bugs at scale. But what stood out in early testing is how quickly Opus 4.6 found vulnerabilities out of the box without task-specific tooling, custom scaffolding, or specialized prompting. Even more interesting is how it found them. Fuzzers work by throwing massive amounts of random inputs at code to see what breaks. Opus 4.6 reads and reasons about code the way a human researcher would­&#8212;looking at past fixes to find similar bugs that weren&#8217;t addressed, spotting patterns that tend to cause problems, or understanding a piece of logic well enough to know exactly what input would break it. When we pointed Opus 4.6 at some of the most well-tested codebases (projects that have had fuzzers running against them for years, ...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: How Top CISOs Solve Burnout and Speed up MTTR without Extra Hiring
item.description: Why do SOC teams keep burning out and missing SLAs even after spending big on security tools? Routine triage piles up, senior specialists get dragged into basic validation, and MTTR climbs, while stealthy threats still find room to slip through. Top CISOs have realized the solution isn’t hiring more people or stacking yet another tool onto the workflow, but giving their teams faster, clearer
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: BridgePay Confirms Ransomware Attack, No Card Data Compromised
item.description: The services of Florida-based payments platform BridgePay are offline due to a ransomware attack

item.title: Bloody Wolf Targets Uzbekistan, Russia Using NetSupport RAT in Spear-Phishing Campaign
item.description: The threat actor known as Bloody Wolf has been linked to a campaign targeting Uzbekistan and Russia to infect systems with a remote access trojan known as NetSupport RAT. Cybersecurity vendor Kaspersky is tracking the activity under the moniker Stan Ghouls. The threat actor is known to be active since at least 2023, orchestrating spear-phishing attacks against manufacturing, finance, and IT
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Social Media Platforms Earn Billions from Scam Ads
item.description: Revolut claims social media sites make £3.8bn annually from scam ads targeting European users

item.title: Researchers Find 40,000+ Exposed OpenClaw Instances
item.description: SecurityScorecard has identified over 40,000 OpenClaw deployments exposed to potential attack

item.title: US Agencies Told to Scrap End of Support Edge Devices
item.description: CISA has issued a new directive requiring federal agencies to decommission all end of support edge devices within 12 months to reduce ongoing exploitation risks

item.title: TeamPCP Worm Exploits Cloud Infrastructure to Build Criminal Infrastructure
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have called attention to a "massive campaign" that has systematically targeted cloud native environments to set up malicious infrastructure for follow-on exploitation. The activity, observed around December 25, 2025, and described as "worm-driven," leveraged exposed Docker APIs, Kubernetes clusters, Ray dashboards, and Redis servers, along with the recently disclosed
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: BeyondTrust Fixes Critical Pre-Auth RCE Vulnerability in Remote Support and PRA
item.description: BeyondTrust has released updates to address a critical security flaw impacting Remote Support (RS) and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products that, if successfully exploited, could result in remote code execution. "BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and certain older versions of Privileged Remote Access (PRA) contain a critical pre-authentication remote code execution vulnerability," the company
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: OpenClaw Integrates VirusTotal Scanning to Detect Malicious ClawHub Skills
item.description: OpenClaw (formerly Moltbot and Clawdbot) has announced that it's partnering with Google-owned VirusTotal to scan skills that are being uploaded to ClawHub, its skill marketplace, as part of broader efforts to bolster the security of the agentic ecosystem. "All skills published to ClawHub are now scanned using VirusTotal's threat intelligence, including their new Code Insight capability,"
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: German Agencies Warn of Signal Phishing Targeting Politicians, Military, Journalists
item.description: Germany's Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution (aka Bundesamt für Verfassungsschutz or BfV) and Federal Office for Information Security (BSI) have issued a joint advisory warning of a malicious cyber campaign undertaken by a likely state-sponsored threat actor that involves carrying out phishing attacks over the Signal messaging app. "The focus is on high-ranking targets in
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Friday Squid Blogging: Squid Fishing Tips
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Asian Cyber Espionage Campaign Breached 37 Countries
item.description: <p>Palo Alto Networks says an Asian cyber espionage campaign breached 70 organizations in 37 countries, targeting government agencies and critical infrastructure.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-asian-cyber-espionage-campaign-breached-37-countries/">Asian Cyber Espionage Campaign Breached 37 Countries</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Kezia Jungco

item.title: I Am in the Epstein Files
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Chinese-Made Malware Kit Targets Chinese-Based Routers and Edge Devices
item.description: DKnife is a Chinese made malware framework that targets Chinese-based users

item.title: 'Encrypt It Already' Campaign Pushes Big Tech to Prioritize E2E Encryption
item.description: The Electronic Frontier Foundation is urging major technology companies to follow through on their promises to implement end-to-end encryption (E2E) by default across their services, as privacy concerns mount amid increased AI use.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman
